relations.head: SLC1A5
relations.label: transport
relations.text: L-glutamine uptake is regulated by SLC1A5 and loss of SLC1A5 function inhibits cell growth and activates autophagy.

relations.head: SLC7A5/SLC3A2
relations.label: transport
relations.text: The molecular basis for L-glutamine sensitivity is due to SLC7A5/SLC3A2, a bidirectional transporter that regulates the simultaneous efflux of L-glutamine out of cells and transport of L-leucine/EAA into cells.

relations.head: SLC7A5/SLC3A2
relations.label: transport
relations.text: The molecular basis for L-glutamine sensitivity is due to SLC7A5/SLC3A2, a bidirectional transporter that regulates the simultaneous efflux of L-glutamine out of cells and transport of L-leucine/EAA into cells.

relations.head: L-glutamine
relations.label: activate
relations.text: We show that cellular uptake of L-glutamine and its subsequent rapid efflux in the presence of essential amino acids (EAA) is the rate-limiting step that activates mTOR.

relations.head: L-leucine
relations.label: activate
relations.text: The molecular basis for L-glutamine sensitivity is due to SLC7A5/SLC3A2, a bidirectional transporter that regulates the simultaneous efflux of L-glutamine out of cells and transport of L-leucine/EAA into cells.

relations.head: Essential amino acids
relations.label: activate
relations.text: We show that cellular uptake of L-glutamine and its subsequent rapid efflux in the presence of essential amino acids (EAA) is the rate-limiting step that activates mTOR.

relations.head: mTOR
relations.label: inhibit
relations.text: Amino acids are required for activation of the mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) kinase which regulates protein translation, cell growth, and autophagy.

relations.head: mTOR
relations.label: upregulate
relations.text: Amino acids are required for activation of the mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) kinase which regulates protein translation, cell growth, and autophagy.

relations.head: mTOR
relations.label: upregulate
relations.text: Amino acids are required for activation of the mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) kinase which regulates protein translation, cell growth, and autophagy.
